Looking at the output of e.g. 'openstack server list --debug' I see some things that correspond to log entries from osc-lib so I think we're good.

This bit of trickery (building a tuple for each value to avoid comparing against None) would benefit from a comment in the source. What you have in the commit message would be a good place to start. That much of a comment is going to make this block of code pretty long, so it might be more cleanly organized by sticking it into a function with a name like `safelySortData()`.

I also suspect that if you replace the first item of the tuple with `type(k[index])` you would avoid all exceptions, but that's a guess and I haven't tested it.

Fair point. Done.

> I also suspect that if you replace the first item of the tuple with `type(k[index])` you would avoid all exceptions, but that's a guess and I haven't tested it.

I tried. No go. 'type' isn't comparable 😞 I could initialize the type, which would work for the primitive types and containers, but won't for objects (like the 'FormattableColumn' subclasses)

  >>> x = [('test', 'foo'), (None, None), ('boo', 'bar'), (1, 2)]
  >>> sorted(x, key=lambda k: (type(k[0]), k[0]))
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: '<' not supported between instances of 'type' and 'type'
Well, bother. We could use the name, but that feels hacky. I guess catching the TypeError is the best option.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Based on the below, I think this needs to be reworded. It confused me. I personally assumed that 'oslo_messaging.MessageUndeliverable' was a subset of 'rpc_amqp.AMQPDestinationNotFound' and all you were doing was improving the logging. It seems what you're actually doing is adding code to handle 'oslo_messaging.MessageUndeliverable' rather than relying on the application to do. How about something like this:

  Currently, setting the '[oslo_messaging] direct_mandatory_flag' config option
  to 'True' (the default) will result in a 'MessageUndeliverable' exception
  being raised when sending a reply if a RabbitMQ queue is missing. It was
  the responsibility of the application to handle this exception, however,
  many applications are not doing so. This has resulted in a number of bug
  reports.

  Start handling this error condition, using a retry loop to attempt to resend
  the message and work around any temporary glitches. Since attempting to send
  a reply will will no longer raise an exception, there is little benefit in
  retaining the '[oslo_messaging] direct_mandatory_flag' config option, since
  users setting this to False will not benefit from the retry logic and
  improved logging added here. As a result, this option is removed entirely.

Obviously you would replace the bit about the option being removed with something like "This option is already deprecated and will be fully removed in a future release" if we decide to keep it a for a while longer

I still don't understand why it's essential that we remove this *right now*. It defaults to True (i.e. mandatory) and anyone overriding it is presumably doing so for a reason. I'd like to wait 6 months for them to consume the version that deprecates this, to allow anyone to argue against deprecation if they have a good reason to keep it. I really don't think anyone will, but it's best practice to at least offer that option.

To be clear, if someone had set 'direct_mandatory_flag' to False then they won't see an exception, meaning this change only affects people using the default or setting it to True, right? I think that's okay.

So calls to '_get_connection' [1] previously raised an exception and we now handle that, meaning behavior has changed for users as they no longer have to/can choose to handle this? That makes sense. What about users who set the flag to False though? Are we removing functionality by removing that option? I suspect the key difference is that setting it to False will cause it to silently fail, rather than failing after a couple of retries with logging (or with an exception as we saw previously)? If so, I guess the change in behavior is very slight and we could remove the option now. However, we're technically breaking the standard deprecation policy [2] so I still think it might be better to retain it and improve the wording of the deprecation message. I will let you make this call though.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.messaging/+/771232/12/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqpdriver.py#147
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/assert_follows-standard-deprecation.html

Well I'm not against leave the flag available however it will not longer behave as described because our goal here is to looping over a timeout by using it.

Now that these changes loop for a timeout when a MessageUndeliverable is raised, it is wrong to say that an exception will be raised. Originally this flag was designed to fail early by raising an exception (MessageUndeliverable) and by letting user handle the case where a queue is missing. By looping for a timeout we no longer raise an exception.

Maybe a compromize could be to leave the flag for awhile but in this case we should reformulating is helping message/doc.

However in this case if a customer disable the flag we will loose the possiblity to know if we face an exchange issue or a missing queue.

Thoughts?
nit: can you wrap under 72 characters?

Also, could we improve the log while we're here. Something like the below would be much clearer IMO:

  LOG.debug(
      'The reply %(msg_id)s could not be sent due to a missing queue, '
      '%(reply_q)s. Retrying...',

Ditto. Also, can we reword this. Something like:

  LOG.info(
      'The reply %(msg_id)s failed to send after %(duration)d seconds '
      'due to a missing queue, %(reply_q)s. Abandoning.',
      {...})

Finally, why is this an info log and not a warning or even error? Are replies not important?

We've always had a ~/.tripleo/ folder, I wonder if it makes sense to put this type of stuff in there rather than straight into a user's home dir

We do write other generated envs like baremetal_deployment.yaml and dervied_parameter.yaml into home dir. ~/.tripleo/environments seems to be the default[1] environment_directory included unless --ennvironment-directory is overridden by the user(magic) and these environments included without user explicitly specifying them in deploy command IMO can always cause issues.   


[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/constants.py#L54-L55

why do we need this here? i see we have it in other places too like https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/commit/625972e07724bb06e73bc72d21a6d98b57bd6310/tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-container-image-prepare.yaml#L39 so I don't think it's a typo ;) but I don't know what it does 
I mean the lookup env HOME will give you the user directory, and ~ is a bash shorthand for the directory so why do we need both here please? thanks :)
ok thanks, your hint helped me find it ... it's a jinja thing apparently https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/master/templates/#other-operators
The ~ operator is used to join operands as strings and not the bash shorthand for home dir here.

It looks like mke2fs < 1.43 had this check, asking for confirmation when attempting to format a whole disk as a fs.

http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/e2fsprogs-release.html#1.43
'Mke2fs no longer complains if the user tries to create a file system using the entire block device (e.g., without using a partition). The minor number convention is not used by all block devices, and it's quite normal in some circumstances to create a file system on /dev/sdc instead of /dev/sdc1.'

IMO, it should be safe to pass that force argument, otherwise people using older mke2fs versions will have issues with this. Alternatively, we can just go back to mkfs.ext4, which was used before this refactoring got merged: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/226979/

The API endpoint should reconstitute this back into a list, so HTTP already supports params which are lists, lets use that.

tempest/config.py.message: Perhaps it's worth mentioning that this is related to pre-provisioned credentials?

I'm not 100% convinced we need to change the default here, both for pre-provisioned and dynamic credentials provider.

The dynamic credential provider would start assigning this role to all users (v2 and v3) regardless of other roles they may have and I don't believe that's a desired behaviour. 

The current logic is that if the identity version in use is v3 and not other role has been assigned yet, then Member will be assigned because in v3 a user must have a role explicitly assigned onto a projects for things to work.

The pre-provisioned credential provider does not expect by default any role to be specified for the accounts (primary and alt), which is good enough for most tests in devstack deployment in the gate. In case of v3 credentials a role is required though, so I believe the solution could be found in having in pre-provisioned credentials provider a logic symmetric with what is done in the dynamic one, that is:
- define a new type which can be used to signify the list of roles configured in tempest_roles
- if not type and no role is found for an account, and if identity_version == v3, exclude it from the list of usable hashes

The alternative is of course to stop the v2/v3 differentiation, and always require a role for v2 credentials as well. It would make the logic simpler, but I would prefer not too, since it may break people already using pre-provisioned credentials for v2.

More opinions on this are welcome.

Thanks Mingyuan for the background info.  Since we identified issues with upgrades and config updates during code review; it would help to provide a list of potentially affected once edgeworker is added.   Then, it may make sense to at least update the api call in some key places (such as was done for the upgrades case). And, recommend to list the known limitations (in commit message), and advise on regression peformed without edgeworkers.

Before the final phase of edgeworker finished, the feature will be tagged as experimental(or something else). 

During the whole development procedure, the principle of adding the edgeworker feature is to introduce as little impact as possible to current logics, especially APIs. Since it's a big change, there are 2 options if the logic has to be impacted inevitably:

- Modify the API logic to keep all logics getting the right return value they expected. e.g. dbapi.ihost_get_list(exclude=<personality>) or exclude edgeworker by default. That requires the review/change at each point when the API is called. No matter whether edgeworker nodes are added to the inventory or not.
or
- During the feature development, endure the alarms that some functionalities are not supported for edgeworker after the edgeworker nodes are added to the inventory. This option keeps all the logic unchanged for a standard deployment and won't impact the system functionality. Eventually an edgeworker node will be treated as a normal host after containerized flock agents deployed.

I fully understand your point that getting all hosts including edgeworker nodes will raise some alarms because of configuration failure. Considering the underlying principle, I choose the later option because if the feature is tagged as experimantal explicitly, it's up to the users to decide whether to try it when it's still under development. At least in this case, a system without edgeworker nodes is fully verified with current logic.

John, I've checked all the places where the dbapi.ihost_get_list() is called, there are 3 situations:
1. The functions restrict to the hosts with specific personalities which does not include 'edgeworker'. Majority of the functions are calling config_update_hosts() with explict personalities.
2. The functions get all hosts and only deal with unlocked and enabled hosts. Obviously currently edgworker node will not be unlocked and enabled.
3. The functions expect to get all hosts. e.g. check whether a hostname is used
Operation with all these situations will not go into unexpected logic, the only exception is the upgrade process which is fixed.
This is also aligned with the test result that the edgeworker host do not generate extra alarm.

Hi John,

The stream of the configuration files goes with 3 steps:
1. Active controller copy the target config files to /tmp/edgeworker/
2. Each edgeworker node remotely copy the config files from controller's /tmp/edgeworker/ to its own dest.
3. After all edgeworker tasks finished, active controller will clean up the /tmp/edgworker folder.

For the multiple user trigger the playbook at the same time, /tmp/edgeworker/<hostname> won't help for the risk condition, because each /tmp/edgeworker/<hostname> will be operated at the same time somehow.

For the one user provisioning process, /tmp/edgeworker won't be an issue because all the config files for each edgeworker node are identical.

is this necessary to get it working? Isn't there already validation when using unsupported interface (as idrac-virtual-media-boot) with selected hardware type (as redfish) that would catch such misconfiguration?

Of course, if somebody configures idrac hardware type with non-Dell server, then it will cause issues. But in this and in more general case, shouldn't there be validation for all interfaces and hardware types across Ironic? For example, to also validate that somebody does not try e.g., iLO with Dell servers?

> Of course, if somebody configures idrac hardware type with non-Dell server, then it will cause issues. 

Exactly.

> But in this and in more general case, shouldn't there be validation for all interfaces and hardware types across Ironic?

I expect most of other drivers to fall quickly and loudly if used with incorrect hardware (e.g. irmc with Dell), but this boot interface is a flavor of Redfish, so the failure is going to be quite obscure (and late).

it's getting complicated :)
- Vendor detection relies on management interface implemented and working, if it is implemented and not working vendor cannot be known, however that also means that baremetal does not support needed vendor.
- Vendor detection works among Redfish and IPMI baremetals, in other cases (WS-Man, iLO etc.) using incorrect configuration should result in empty vendor
- For Redfish and IPMI could assume that by default if vendor can be detected, then it is supported with exception of Redfish virtual media boot for iDRAC
- For idrac hw type all non-Dell vendors should fail for all interfaces, even if somehow user could live with idrac-redfish implementation for some time
- for other vendor specific hw types the same - should fail if vendor cannot be detected, but that's just to replace current error message when it fails to connect (I haven't tried so not sure how self-explanatory it is)
- Something that I have missed or overlooked (further tinkering needed)

On the other hand I don't believe users misconfigure their ironic so that they pick incorrect vendor specific hw type that is meant for different vendor. Effort might not be worth it, but then it's just this inconsistency across interface validation.
I don't object to that, if you have any specific ideas - please propose them.

> On the other hand I don't believe users misconfigure their ironic so that they pick incorrect vendor specific hw type that is meant for different vendor.

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
so if we're shrinking or shrunk, we merge in whatever other shard ranges came back from the root

which will *always* include *at least* the root shard range itself (possibly in SHARDED state) but if *thats* the case we'll ALSO expect some ACTIVE acceptors

We do NOT expect acceptors to be in any state other than ACTIVE, and we don't expect ACTIVE acceptors AND an active root - but we're not enforcing any of that HERE before we merge in

if we're shrinking or shrunk - what the root gives we accept

having written a unit test...turns out that with active root and acceptor the shard might cleave to both! which would also eventually resolve but is unnecessary work. I'm inclined to add a check for overlaps in shard audit and just stall rather than try to deal with all cleaving scenarios.

correct

if we did end up with ACTIVE acceptor and ACTIVE root (split-brain shrink), then (and I guess a probe test would be nice to verify this...) the shard would cleave to one of them (the acceptor would sort first unless the acceptor's upper=MAX, in which case root would sort first), and cleaving would complete - so the shard would shrink. The root would eventually resolve the acceptor clash, and that might mean there's now misplaced objects from the shrunk shard in either root or the (mistaken) acceptor, so they should get moved by misplaced object correction.

Or, we could check for overlaps (which would be the case with an active root and active acceptor) and refuse to cleave; then wait for the root to resolve itself.

At one point I considered making root shard ranges *always* sort last...not sure if that is essential though.
specifically we'd never get to this elif because it *is* ACTIVE and was handled above in the _cleave_shard_range block

correct

is the comment confusing? - I meant it to justify the elif condition
I'm sure this loop is what was giving Tim nightmares, and we've had to make a few minor tweeks while working on shrinking overlaps
I think I have seen the loop stop making progress if a FOUND shard overlaps...something like the found never becomes created so we just keep landing in the else case here????

So the shrinking shards are filtered out here, rather then skipped below.

One additional benefit of the pull baed model is if somewhow the acceptor shardrange gets big enough to shard (though not sure how that's possible expect for a in a split-brain network situation) then a new accetor will be given to the the SHRINKING shard the next time the SHRINKING shard is audited because of the overlap.
Yeah, it's much cleaner, I like it!

> So the shrinking shards are filtered out here, rather then skipped below.

This should make no difference to the behaviour, just an attempt to make code a bit clearer
So we are now breaking if we find a root in the SHARDED state? This is different then before, or am I missing where SHARDED was filtered out?

OK got it, because when we sort the ranges in broker.get_shard_ranges() we use the ShardRange.sort_key which garantees that an sharded root would come last, because it's sorted first by Upper, then State (and ACTIVE < SHARDED), then Lower (and it'll be the lowest), and the name but we shouldn't need to get this far. In fact the first two in most instances would be enough. Nice!

Depends on which 'before' :) :

- on master, root ranges don't make it into the shards

- in last patchset the cleave loop might have iterated to a sharded root, which it would then ignore (an I added a log about it being ignored). But the fact that the loop even found the sharded root was a quirk: on master the loop does not break when cleaving_done becomes true i.e. for a batch size of 2, the first shard of the two might have upper >= the shrinking shard's upper, so cleaving is done, but the loop would still iterate to the second in the batch, which could now be an irrelevant sharded root range.

In this patchset the loop breaks as soon as cleaving_done becomes true so we should never get to the irrelevant sharded root (because there should be an active acceptor to which cleaving completes that would sort ahead of the root), but if we do reach  sharded root (unexpected case) then the 'Stopped cleave at unready...' will be logged.
This was the only place we call range_done() with None; can we just drop the `if` up at L320?
Done
... or fewer, if we wrote down the context back when we were still counting SHRINKING ranges as "todo".

Done.

Note to self: cleaving_context.ranges_todo has no bearing on the cleave operation other than in logging, and it is not clear that it needs to be persisted, other than for inspection of the cleaving_context by humans perhaps.
OK, and we're relying on the (upper, state, lower) ordering to keep that root range at the end of the list and not trip the 'Stopped cleave at unready' message.
yes. In a previous version (before fixing the loop) I had needed a special case to trap the irrelevant sharded root range to avoid triggering the 'Stopped cleave at unready' log.
Off-topic: I'm still nervous that we don't have anything in the audits to ensure that the ranges in these states will cover our section of the namespace :-/
Ack
Sounds like a good feature request so we don't follow up on this at some point.

oslo_utils/netutils.py.message:
We're supposed to be an abstraction layer over the underlying library so I don't think we need to expose the exact same semantics. As this stands, someone would need to read the netaddr docs, at which point they'd surely be better off just using netutil? As far as I can tell from reading, the old 'inet_aton' behavior is deprecated and 'inet_pton' should be preferred [1] since it supports IPv6 [2]. That's irrelevant though and what we actually care about here is that 'inet_pton' only accepts the "presentation format", which is much stricter (only 'a.b.c.d', and nothing else) rather than the address format ('a.b.c.d', 'a.b.c', 'a.b' or 'a') supported by 'inet_pton'. Given we only care about the 'INET_PTON' flag (since it get us this "strict" behavior) and not the other 'ZEROFILL' flag, could we add a ternary 'strict' flag? We might want to look at enabling that by default, with something like this:

  if strict is None,
    try to convert in strict mode
    if conversion passes
      return True
    else
      try to convert in non-strict mode
      if conversion passes
        log a warning stating that this behavior is deprecated and you should pass strict=False if
        you want to preserve legacy behavior,
        return True
      else
        return False
  else
    if strict is True:
      try to convert in strict mode,
      return result
    else
      try to convert in non-strict mode,
      return result

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/a/5328184/613428
[2] https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/SSLTBW_2.3.0/com.ibm.zos.v2r3.bpxbd00/ipton.htm
Can you add a versionchanged directive?

this isn't necessary - you can rely on the truthy check. You could also do

  strict and INEP_PTON or 0
nit: you can drop this and dent the entire block. The above block will always return if we enter it
why isn't this a boolean default to False instead? I guess the code would get way less complex.
Because we want to move to setting it to True in the future. If we set it to False, we have no way to warn users that are relying on the current value (False) that it will be changing soon
Do we want this to be a log, or should we use 'warnings' and emit a DeprecationWarning?
For what it's worth, I see examples of both here. warnings might be better since that's explicitly what it's designed for, but I'm okay with this approach also

releasenotes/notes/allow-to-convert-ipv4.message:
This isn't that helpful. The 'is_valid_ipv4' function doesn't convert anything, at least not that the user can see. As far as the user is concerned, it simply checks if an IP address is valid. What you're trying to do is avoid things like 'is_valid_ipv4(10)' being accepted. As noted previously, those are valid IP addresses if using the 'aton' flag but not if using the 'pton' flag but I suspect that most people actually expect the pton behavior. Can you reword this saying something like

  Add a ``strict`` flag allowing users to restrict validation to IP addresses in
  presentation format (``a.b.c.d``) as opposed to address format (``a.b.c.d``,
  ``a.b.c``, ``a.b``, ``a``).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I feel like I make it sound like this is no longer desirable/allowed/supported. That's not the case.
Having different kinds of API endpoint interfaces is transparent to manila. Just that, we initially thought we could have our API differ with the endpoints - that's no longer the design.

In deployments, it's possible that there are different networks that the API is available on, and these "admin", "public" and "internal" endpoints correspond to these different networks. The Manila API behaves the same way, no matter the interface.

True, we can document that with noauth, the project_id they make up shouldn't clash with manila URI resource names. For example, you can't have a project_id called "share".

The only other place where I see project_id in URLs is the quota APIs where project_id can be a path parameter - however, there's no pagination support for our quota APIs, yet, so this code won't hurt them:

 https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/shared-file-system/#quota-sets


For future proofing, I can make this better by looking for a regex that matches (/v2/project_id)

Agree, but this way when this comparison is removed (in Y), we'll need only to remove this section without fixing the indentation of L97-L102. That will keep better the git history in this file.

Events are grouped per ResourceUpdate.id. All events ID is the network ID. Two ports belonging to different networks won't be compared.
no need for subnet_id if check net ids above

As commented, all events belong to a single network. But Neutron API don't allow IP CIDR overlapping, that means IP addresses of different networks can't collide. I'll remove the subnet_id because that's not needed.
so in case when there is any common IP address between those two resources we will ignore priority, and always process older event first. This makes sense for me.
Exactly, that's the goal here. That will prevent the situation described in the bug.

The resource is a generic blob, that can be an incomplete dictionary describing the object parameters. Instead of changing something that is sent by the server, I prefer to add an explicit parameter to describe the object type. We cannot retrieve the object type from the resource parameter.
Why do we need this change for nets and subnets?

For consistency. The elements added to self._queue are stored in a single queue and compared all together. When inserting an element in ExclusiveResourceProcessor, the priority queue is the same for all elements belonging to the same network (resource ID). All element events (network, subnets and ports) will be prioritized in this queue using the above method class.

This is necessary so that /api/tenant/foo/builds can still return 404 as it currently does.

However, I think we should keep the cache time very low.  We're already effectively doing an RPC call on each hit to /builds; any caching is an optimization.  However, a long cache will mean that adding a tenant won't be reflected in the web ui, and the first thing I would do as a user after adding a tenant is to check the web ui.  Let's set this to 60 seconds for now.  Once we start using ZK, we shouldn't need this anymore.

There were some unit test failures related to caching (because they wanted to look up the number of items in the queue for a tenant, and were getting old cached values).  I cleared the cache in the unit tests to handle that.

deployment/nova/nova-compute-container-p.message: Sorry, I don't understand what this sentence is trying to convey.

we take the default GlanceRbdPoolName, but glance supports multistore to add additional backends. the intend is to be able to override the default pool to one of the additional configured backends for this compute role. I now see that when using multiple stores we
also need  to be able to set a different CephClusterName/CephClientUserName. I'll update the patch to have parameters for this.

well thinking about this again it does not make sense to support override CephClusterName/CephClientUserName. as it will be a different ceph cluster from where the ephemeral nova disks are located, it'll end up in using the api download process anyways.

iiuc here you're overriding the GlanceRBDPool (which is used in the glance config) if some conditions are met (nova_glance_rbd_pool_name_set and a few others).
Maybe I'm missing some logic into puppet but the purpose here is to use NovaGlanceRbdPoolName instead of the default variable only when rbd download is enabled, right?
This is ok since you're supporting multiple instances via puppet but I'm wondering if it's better having a dictionary containing multiple configurations for multiple instances of the puppet resource.
In addition, should the CephPools value (where a different pool != from the default one) needs to be checked?
Do you mean "override"? That would make more sense to me.
yes override, had to lookup the different meaning between overwrite and override as the translation of the word itself is the same 😊
+1 since this is the location resolved within the container.

This NovaGlanceRbdDownloadMultistoreConfig approach certainly works, but I'm mentioning an alternative just so it's recorded.

An alternative might be to define a NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID parameter, which the user would use to specify the GlanceBackendID associated with this "direct download" feature. If NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID equals GlanceBackendID then you know they want to use glance's default cluster/pool/user values. Otherwise, they want you to pull the values from GlanceMultistoreConfig using NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID as the key.

You might also be able to eliminate the NovaGlanceEnableRbdDownload boolean by inference. Assume False if NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID is empty (''), and True if it's not.

> This NovaGlanceRbdDownloadMultistoreConfig approach certainly works, but I'm mentioning an alternative just so it's recorded.
> 
> An alternative might be to define a NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID parameter, which the user would use to specify the GlanceBackendID associated with this "direct download" feature. If NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID equals GlanceBackendID then you know they want to use glance's default cluster/pool/user values. Otherwise, they want you to pull the values from GlanceMultistoreConfig using NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID as the key.

yes, that's an alternative,

> 
> You might also be able to eliminate the NovaGlanceEnableRbdDownload boolean by inference. Assume False if NovaGlanceRbdDownloadBackendID is empty (''), and True if it's not.

From discussion with Lee we agreed that this is a corner case config and we don't what this to be enabled per default, at least not atm. When we want it to be automatically enabled we can do a check like this. Thanks for the suggestion!
In general I agree with the approach proposed by Alan, but I also see the motivation of this kind of definition, so +1 on my side
The NovaGlanceRbdDownloadMultistoreConfig param name suggests it's more than just an ID. NovaGlanceRbdDownloadMultistoreID might be clearer.
Ack, makes sense. Updated in the latest
nice! It will bomb if the user specifies an invalid NovaGlanceRbdDownloadMultistoreConfig, but hopefully it will do so in a way that helps the user understand what they did wrong.

This can probably be solved by an additional validation step (a tripleo-validation set of tasks ) where both the fields and the content of a given data structure can be evaluated with a specific logic.
I guess this is not required here, but adding (at the right step) an "in-flight" validation can help checking values and return a more user friendly/verbose error.

nova/compute/api.py.message:
It looks to me and I maybe wrong, that there are some other places for placementclient.delete_allocation_for_instance. For example, L2176.
Placement allocations are cleaned up either on the compute or via _local_delete. It other cases allocations may be left.

If instance is None the call to _local_delete_cleanup is going to fail with an attribute error when we reference instance.uuid.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1892837?

This is correct -- this patch has caused a regression in our handling of delete racing with build:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1914174

_local_delete_cleanup should not be called if instance = None, so I'm not sure what the rationale was here.

nova/tests/functional/test_servers.py.message: nit: use one of these words
Looking at the code I think you are right. A conductor restart while the scheduler is handling the requests causes the leak.

What a magnificent hack. But I don't have a better solution. I've tried stopping / killing the conductor service when _ensure_sufficient_hosts() is hit but it makes everything hanging. (I guess .kill() waits for RPC to return which waits for scheduler to return from select_destination which waits for _ensure_sufficient_hosts to return. So we have a deadlock)
Sometimes we only have is a hack. at least this hack is in a test not in the production code.
Yes I also gone into many dead end before this solution
this was renamed to _build_server() in the meantime this is while the functional job now fails for your patch
My bad, I did not check functional after rebase, nova code is moving so fast! Thank you for pointing this.

doc/source/devref/service_support.rst.message: it might be better to specify "before Service"
perhaps rephrase to: "handler creates the CRD with the endpoints subsets, otherwise the existent CRD is updated".
the status part holds details about the Neutron resources and is updated whenever some changes on the crd spec have happened.
might be good to include delete events as well, or make it more general and state only "events"
perhaps this can be more generic and only mention events regardless of the type.

note that is the status that contain these fields https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kubernetes_crds/kuryr_crds/kuryrloadbalancer.yaml#L113, perhaps this needs to be moved to line 78?

perhaps rephrase it to:

- KuryrLoadBalancerHandler manages KuryrLoadBalancer CRD events when the CRD is successfully created and filled with spec data. This handler is responsible for creating the needed Octavia resources according to the CRD spec and update the status field with information about the generated resources, such as LoadBalancer, LoadBalancerListener, LoadBalancerPool and LoadBalancerMembers.

That's a bit generic info about finalizers, maybe something like this:

In order to prevent Kubernetes objects from being deleted before the OpenStack resources are cleaned up, finalizers are used. Those block deletion of the Service, Endpoints and KuryrLoadBalancers objects until Kuryr deletes the associated OpenStack loadbalancers and only then the finalizers are removed allowing the Kubernetes API to delete the objects.
